ygData.subject: Re: ANJI : NEAT implementation (fingerprint implementation issues)
ygData.msgSnippet: I think that it s best to generalize that. We can keep the existing CPPN way of activation and add to it. We can have, say y=f(x) nodes, (x1, y1) = f(x, y)

I think that it's best to generalize that. We can keep the existing 
CPPN w=
ay of activation and add to it. We can have, say y=3Df(x) nodes, 
(x1, y1) =
=3D f(x, y) nodes, z =3D f(x, y) nodes and so on. It is just 
additional st=
ages of the activation.. I am thinking for a possible 
implementation of it=
 right now. 

Peter

ey@...> wrote:

ce could

l

ition neural networks.  That's part of why I made the decision 
to

these representations CPPNs rather than neural networks.  
>

e post to which you just replied described just such an 
> activation funct=
ion, i.e. one that takes two arguments and converts

me to polar.

> >

imiting to explore or "experiment" with, to evaluate potential

tive activation functions. It is like trying to paint a

 only black paint on a white canvas. You can identify primary

> > --- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Her=
e are my thoughts after reading through this very 
interesting 
> > > conve=
rsation.
> > > 
> > > First, I agree rotation is an important issue for Hyp=
erNEAT; 
> > however, 
> > > I am confident that is can be dealt with.  It'=
s an interesting 
> open 
> > > research problem.
> > > 
> > > In any case,=
 there is an important aspect of this issue that we 
> > > should also be c=
onsidering.  The problem is not simply to be 
able 
> > to 
> > > perform a=
 rotation. As Jason's posts imply (and Peter stated), 
> > > HyperNEAT and =
CPPNs should technically already be able to 
perform 
> > > rotations.  And=
, in fact, they do.  When I play with God Mode 
in 
> > > genetic art I oft=
en find weights that when adjusted rotate a 
part 
> > of 
> > > the image.=
  That is not that unusual (although perhaps not as 
> usual 
> > > as we'd=
 like either).
> > > 
> > > However, that kind of rotation actually *isn't*=
 the type we 
> really 
> > > need.  The issue is not that a particular sha=
pe should be 
> possible 
> > to 
> > > rotate some arbitrary angle by chan=
ging some weights. Recall 
that 
> > > CPPNs work by laying out coordinate =
frames within which higher 
> > > strucutres are situated.  To create a sym=
metric coordinate 
frame 
> > means
> > > creating a gradient with *two* si=
des, both the opposite of each 
> > > other.  That is, symmetry is not crea=
ted by flipping a gradient 
> > from 
> > > one side to the other, but rath=
er by having both sides at the 
> same 
> > > time.
> > > 
> > > Therefore,=
 a rotational coordinate frame should actually 
contain 
> > > something ak=
in to a sinusoidal gradient that spreads around a 
> > circle 
> > > rather=
 than along a line. Then, structures situated within its 
> > > coordinate =
frame would repeat in a rotated regular pattern, 
like 
> > > petals on a f=
lower (that way you get rotatonal invariance).  
> > > 
> > > Thus what we =
really want is to be able to feed in a regular 2D 
> > > coordinate frame a=
nd output another coordinate frame that is a 
> sine 
> > > wave around a c=
ircle in 2D as well.  In other words:
> > > 
> > > f(x,y)=3Da point in this=
 circular petal-like gradient
> > > 
> > > Thus we only need to define a fu=
nction like that and make it an 
> > > activation function that takes two d=
istinct inputs.
> > > 
> > > However, the problem does remain of where to c=
ontrol the period 
> of 
> > > repetition around the circle.
> > > 
> > > A=
ctually, thinking of it now, what we really want is NOT what I 
> > just 
>=
 > > said but rather something a bit different that would solve the 
> > > =
problem I just posed: What we want is a function f(x,y) that 
> > produces =

> > > a gradient that starts at 0 on e.g. the x axis and then 
increases 
=
> > up 
> > > to 1 as you rotate around the origin to 360 degrees.
> > > 
>=
 > > That way, you have a true circular/polar coordinate system.  
Then 
> =
> you 
> > > can simply run its output into a sine wave, and you get the 
>=
 > > repetition around the circle that I describe above.  Then the 
> > > f=
requency of repetition is controlled very easily by varying 
the 
> > > wei=
ght leaving the polar function and entering the sine wave, 
> just 
> > > a=
s in any normal CPPN!
> > > 
> > > So I guess my conclusion is we just need=
 a function that 
converts 
> > > Cartesian coordinates to a polar angle, a=
nd then running its 
> output 
> > > into a periodic activation function wi=
ll give your nice 
> rotational 
> > > repetition, which in a neural substr=
ate is rotational 
invariance!
> > > 
> > > Hmm...so I think this explains =
in part how to deal with the 
> issue, 
> > > though maybe not 100% (it doe=
sn't explain what it means if the 
> > inputs 
> > > to such a polar conver=
sion function are not the base-level x 
and 
> y, 
> > > but I think such c=
ases will actually yield nice localized 
> > rotational 
> > > effects as w=
ell).  
> > > 
> > > Sorry for writing out my thoughts as they come to me i=
n stream 
of 
> > > consciousness- this is a rare case where I'm thinking o=
f ideas 
as 
> I 
> > > write!
> > > 
> > > ken
